data.text: Robust Touring Bicycles from Old MTBs

A robust and low budget touring set up can be based on an older mountain bike. There are plenty of older ones, often sold for very little because they don't meet current trends in MTB design.They are without suspension, with cantilever or other good rim breaks and some made from high end tubing like Reynolds,Tange or Columbus. Some even have braised on rack luggs as they were more conceived of as trail bikes than real rough off road rock hoppers, (although 'Rock hopper' made some like this!) Being able to fit a rack to braised on mounts is handy if you want to carry much gear and any frame fitted with them should have a touring frameset which if butted will have thicker walls in the seat tube and other places, although MTB frametube sets are similarly robust. On a road racing frame, due to thinner tube walls in certain vital places,with laden panniers, things can get a bit hairy on downhills with frame judder, which can affect steering. So,many older non suspension MTBs, if made from descent tubing make very robust tourers,fitted with appropriate tyres and they can be bought for next to nothing if you're lucky. I have one made from Reynolds 531, probably from the early 1990s.
Using my old Trek 4300 Disc as mtb, commuter, touring, fishingtrips, shoppings. Just put on a rear rack, fenders, saddlebags and a homemade single wheel trailer. Works as a charm.

data.text: It's the knobbly tyres that cause the most drag on an MTB. You can either put some road tread ones on there, or there are some trail tyres with knobbly sides, but a continuous narrow mid-section, so if you pump them to full pressure and are on roads, the knobbly tread stays off the road 'till you hit mud or other yielding surfaces.

data.text: Touring with a mountain bike has one big problem - shorter chain stays. This means that with any reasonable size panniers the rider's heel can strike the pannier. If the really good (stromg) rear rack is somehow shifted back further - this heel strike can be eliminated.

data.text: My most ridden bike. It's steel lugged 1990 model. No the frame hasn't rusted thru and it still climbs as long as my lungs are up for it. Originally marketed as a "Comp" model, I changed the stem and bars to fit ME and added a sprung saddle for all day comfort. Rear rack and trunk bag for practicality. Sure I could possibly tour on it but I just prefer the efficiency of 700x3x tires in a proper tour bike. Just me

data.text: it was a bit of a chore to fit. I ended up moving the rack higher up the fork because my panniers were just inches off the ground. The rack itself is super solid once it's on. BTW, sweet ride!
